Tyler Forgione

Computer Science & Psychology @ McGill. ML · NLP · Computer Vision · Systems.

Hello! My name is Tyler and I'm a Computer Science student at McGill University from Montréal, QC. I have previously completed a degree in Honours Psychology, also at McGill. Most of my interest lies in Machine Learning: Computer Vision and Natural Language Processing mostly. Along with that, I love to work with sports analytics/statistics; though mostly baseball and hockey.

Projects

A few of my recent projects and papers. See the full list on the Projects page.

License Plate Recognition with YOLOv11 + CRNN

Area: Computer Vision Year: 2025 Status: Project

Used YOLOv11 to detect license plates in cluttered street scenes and then trained a bidirectional LSTM to read the license plate characters.

PyTorch YOLOv11 CRNN CTC OpenCV
Code

Pointwise Mutual Information Word Co-occurrence Matrix

Area: NLP Year: 2025 Status: Project

Implemented Latent Semantic Analysis from scratch by computing pointwise mutual information on a word co-occurence matrix and then performing singular value decomposition.

Python Sparse Matrices PMI SVD
Code

Papers

You can see all my papers in the Papers page!

Automated License Plate Recognition with Optical Character Recongition

Authors: Tyler Forgione Year: 2026 Status: Completed
Read PDF
Abstract

In this project, two models were trained and combined: an automated license plate recognition model and an optical character recognition model. The license plate recognition model was trained on over 7000 images of street scenes containing zero or more license plates. This model was then used to find license plates in a dataset with images containing one or more license plates. Finally, these images were used to train a character recognition model used to read the license plates.

Latent Semantic Analysis

Authors: Tyler Forgione Year: 2025 Status: Completed
Read PDF
Abstract

In this project, a Latent Semantic Analysis model was trained on Wikitext-103, a dataset of over 100 million tokens. The model only kept words that were used at least 25 times and was projected onto a 300 dimension latent space. It was then tested on numerous word-similarity and analogy tests and performed relatively well given the training corpus size as well as the minimum count set in the vocabulary. In the future, this model will be compared to simpler and more complex models in order to get a benchmark for semantic models.
